pr_title: HBASE-23977 : Resolve flakes present in TestSlowLogRecorder

timeline.message: HBASE-23977 : Resolve flakes present in TestSlowLogRecorder
HBASE-23977 : Resolve flakes present in TestSlowLogRecorder

timeline.bodyText: nit: intermediate boolean values aren't necessary... just return foo && bar && baz.
timeline.author: ndimiduk

replies.bodyText:
I agree but this is just for better readability. Should be fine to keep it this way?
Especially because statements are bit longer and hence these variables can help with better readability?
replies.author: virajjasani
ndimiduk

timeline.bodyText: I don't understand why these tests are executed within the timeout window. How does that make the tests more reliable?
timeline.author: ndimiduk

replies.bodyText: Since we are dealing with parallel processing and we are expecting consumer of ring buffer to get done with ordered events, but based on env, consumer might not be done by the time we expect ordered events present and hence we want to introduce time lag until we get that specific end result of expected ordered list of events in ring buffer. Sounds good @ndimiduk  ?
replies.author: virajjasani

replies.bodyText: e.g if we send {1,2,3,4,5,6,7} to RingBuffer of size 8, then all of them are consumed in same order. Now if we send {8,9,10,11}, we expect final output from RingBuffer consumer to be {9,10,11,4,5,6,7,8}  (1,2,3 are overridden). However, the reason why we have flakes is because by the time we expect above output, consumer might not have consumed say 10 and 11 and hence actual output would be {9,2,3,4,5,6,7,8}. And hence the failures, so now with waitFor(), we wait until we get ordered output {9,10,11,4,5,6,7,8}, which is why we will wait for all of 8,9,10,11 to be consumed and put in the queue in correct order i.e. no flakes.
replies.author: virajjasani

replies.bodyText:
Oh, I see. So you're actually using waitFor as a retry mechanism. That's not how I imagined using it, but so long as those inner asserts don't interfere with the retry, I guess that's fine.
What happens when the inner Assert.assertEquals(slowLogPayloadsList.size(), 7); throws? Does waitFor retry that, or does it simply fail? If the latter, the test is still flakey. I would loop until I have all the data and then perform the asserts at the end.
replies.author: ndimiduk

replies.bodyText:
oops, my bad, I missed Assert.assertEquals(slowLogPayloadsList.size(), 7);, this still makes it flakey as it fails. Let me take care of it in Addendum.
Thanks @ndimiduk
replies.author: virajjasani

timeline.author: ndimiduk

timeline.bodyText: Yeah, so here's the example where all these intermediate variables make this hard to know it's correct on a quick glance. If it was a chain of return foo && bar && biz && ..., it's obvious that all components are considered.
timeline.author: ndimiduk

replies.bodyText: yeah, makes sense, let me take it up. Thanks
replies.author: virajjasani
